channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Afghanistan: US investigates civilian deaths in Kabul strike
item.description: Six children were among 10 killed in the strike which the US said was meant to stop a militant attack.

item.title: Hurricane Ida: One million people in Louisiana without power
item.description: Louisiana is assessing the damage after the storm knocked out power for nearly one million people.

item.title: Covid: EU recommends new travel restrictions for US as cases rise
item.description: The European Union has recommend barring American travellers as US hospital admissions peak.

item.title: Highly polluting leaded petrol now eradicated from the world, says UN
item.description: The highly polluting fuel has contaminated the atmosphere, water and crops for nearly a century.

item.title: China cuts children's online gaming to one hour
item.description: Regulators are restricting game-playing for under 18s to an hour on Fridays, weekends and holidays

item.title: Palestinian President Abbas holds rare talks with Israeli minister
item.description: It was the Palestinian president's first official meeting with a senior Israeli since 2010.

item.title: Covid surge 'deeply worrying' in Europe as vaccinations dip - WHO
item.description: Europe could see another 236,000 deaths by December as vaccinations slow, a WHO official predicts.

item.title: Kanye West: Donda released by Universal without my say, artist claims
item.description: The rapper says his record label released his delayed 10th album without his permission.

item.title: Brazil bank robbers tie hostages to getaway cars in Araçatuba
item.description: Armed gang members took hostages as human shields, after a bank robbery in Brazil.

item.title: New Zealand woman dies after receiving Pfizer vaccine
item.description: Officials say she also had other medical issues which could have contributed to her death.

item.title: Milan fire: Flames engulf modern 20-storey block of flats
item.description: The tower is only 10 years old and questions are being asked about how the fire spread so dramatically.

item.title: Theranos scandal: Who is Elizabeth Holmes and why is she on trial?
item.description: The former boss of blood testing company Theranos is accused of fraud and could face years in jail.

item.title: Nigerian students amass degrees to stay in Europe
item.description: Modupe Osunkoya enrolled on her third post-graduate degree because she says there are no jobs at home.

item.title: Para-Taekwondo: Taking 360 tornado kicks to Tokyo
item.description: For the first time, the Paralympic games will host a Para-Taekwondo competition.

item.title: Fury as Covid crisis hits Australia's Aboriginal communities
item.description: Indigenous Australians say surging infections in remote areas should have been prevented.

item.title: Can apps move the #MeToo movement forward?
item.description: Reporting sexual harassment at work is getting easier thanks to new technologies.

item.title: Japan's huge army of under-employed ex-housewives
item.description: Why women are still battling for better jobs in the world's third largest economy.

item.title: The moment the US declares it has left Afghanistan
item.description: Top US general reveals last US aircraft took off from Hamid Karzai Airport ahead of deadline for withdrawal.

item.title: Gunfire as Taliban celebrate US leaving Afghanistan
item.description: Gunfire rang out as the BBC's Lyse Doucet reported on US troops' departure from Kabul.

item.title: Afghanistan drone strike: 'Ten people died here.. including my daughter'
item.description: A family comb through rubble for remains of relatives they say were killed by a US drone strike.

item.title: From Bush to Biden: One war, four US presidents on Afghanistan
item.description: Two decades of conflict in Afghanistan shaped the legacies of each of these commanders-in-chief.

item.title: Hurricane Ida: Louisiana assesses damage after storm
item.description: A million people in Louisiana are still are without electricity after a devastating storm hit.

item.title: Afghanistan: Fleeing the Taliban into Pakistan and leaving dreams behind
item.description: The BBC speaks to Afghans fleeing the Taliban into Pakistan at the Chaman Spin Boldak border.

item.title: Afghan left behind by UK: I'm fighting to stay alive
item.description: An Afghan who had authorisation to fly to the UK speaks to the BBC about his struggle to escape.

item.title: Afghanistan: Black Hawks and Humvees - military kit now with the Taliban
item.description: As the insurgents swept through Afghanistan they inherited an arsenal of US-made equipment.

item.title: A country abandoned: BBC's John Simpson on Afghanistan
item.description: As foreign forces end their 20-year campaign, our world affairs editor considers what has been achieved.

item.title: Herat under the Taliban: residents on the new rulers
item.description: People in Afghanistan’s third-largest city, Herat, explain how life has changed in recent weeks.
